citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The nails on the black-tailed prairie dog, rabbit, two ferrets, and skunk need to be trimmed. The nails on each of these
regulated animals are too long. The licensee has not kept the animals on a regular nail trimming schedule and as a result
the nails are 1 to 2 inches in length, approximately a half inch too long for each animal listed.
The lack of adequate and timely nail trims can cause possible injuries and discomfort to the animals due to twisting of the
toes or inability to lay thier feet flat while walking. There is an increase for chances of injury due to nails getting caught on
surfaces or broken due to increased length.
The licensee must keep up nail maintenance on all regulated animals, keeping thier nails trimmed short enough to
prevent injurys or discomfort to the animals when they walk flat on the ground or during climbing activities.
To be corrected by: March 10, 2024

The chinchilla primary enclosure has two plastic shelves that have been chewed along the entire long edge of both
shelves, including two large holes approximately 3-3.5 inches in diameter on each shelf.
The chewed surfaces and holes in the shelves can cause the structure to become weakend and provide a possible
source of injury if the animal were to fall through or get stuck trying to climb through one of the holes in the shelf.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by: March 17, 2024

The food bowl in the chinchilla enclosure contained food pellets that were contaminated with fecal pellets. The bowl is
located on the bottom floor of the enclosure and the chinchilla appears to defecate from the top shelf causing the fecal
pellets to fall into the food bowl, contaminating the food.
The contamination of food by fecal material can be a possible health hazard for the regulated animal, causing potential for
disease or other health issues.
The food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to
maintain all animals in good health.
To be corrected by: The food bowl was cleaned and moved during the inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The nails on the black-tailed prairie dog, rabbit, two ferrets, and skunk need to be trimmed. The nails on each of these 
regulated animals are too long. The licensee has not kept the animals on a regular nail trimming schedule and as a result 
the nails are 1 to 2 inches in length, approximately a half inch too long for each animal listed. 
 
The lack of adequate and timely nail trims can cause possible injuries and discomfort to the animals due to twisting of the 
toes or inability to lay thier feet flat while walking. There is an increase for chances of injury due to nails getting caught on 
surfaces or broken due to increased length. 
 
The licensee must keep up nail maintenance on all regulated animals, keeping thier nails trimmed short enough to 
prevent injurys or discomfort to the animals when they walk flat on the ground or during climbing activities.  
 
To be corrected by: March 10, 2024 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The chinchilla primary enclosure has two plastic shelves that have been chewed along the entire long edge of both 
shelves, including two large holes approximately 3-3.5 inches in diameter on each shelf.  
 
The chewed surfaces and holes in the shelves can cause the structure to become weakend and provide a possible 
source of injury if the animal were to fall through or get stuck trying to climb through one of the holes in the shelf. 
 
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
To be corrected by: March 17, 2024 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding.

The food bowl in the chinchilla enclosure contained food pellets that were contaminated with fecal pellets. The bowl is 
located on the bottom floor of the enclosure and the chinchilla appears to defecate from the top shelf causing the fecal 
pellets to fall into the food bowl, contaminating the food. 
 
The contamination of food by fecal material can be a possible health hazard for the regulated animal, causing potential for 
disease or other health issues. 
 
The food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to 
maintain all animals in good health. 
 
To be corrected by: The food bowl was cleaned and moved during the inspection 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
